fields.description:
"People" should be sorted by a visible field such that it is intuitive and usable.

This is particular bad for companies that have a "global id" where the username is a number which indicates something closer to "sequence of hiring" than anything that would be useful to search by. However, even in cases where "Mark Mielke" maps to "markm", "John Mason" might map to "mason". Unless the username is shown, it makes no sense to sort by username.

My preference would be to sort by the primary column, and for the primary column and sort key to be the fullname.
fields.summary: "People" listing is sorted by username but displayed by fullname. Order appears random which makes it hard to find users by browsing.

fields.description: !http://content.screencast.com/users/tpettersen/folders/Jing/media/1187702b-c954-41be-b9ec-c7f829d4d744/2009-11-21_1317.png!
fields.summary: Deleted users names are not shown in review history.

fields.description: When creating a review through JIRA's issue tab panel and trying to remove a CS from the review, the files associated with that CS remains in the review. They appear as "new" files, so my guess is that it assumes it to be a patch that's sitting around
fields.summary: Files aren't removed from a review when the CS is removed

fields.description:
Refer to [CRC-1202|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CRC-1202].

It would be good to have an option to set whether an upload file should be binary or text in a review. (e.g using the "Uploads" tab).
fields.summary: Able to set whether an upload file should be binary or text in a review

fields.description:
*Steps*
1. Go to a file that has source (inline) comments and long source lines such that there is a horizontal scrollbar.
2. Click the _Prefs_ menu and select _Source comments: Above_

*Expected*
- After step 1, the inline comments should be resized to the width of the viewport, whilst the source lines extend out.
- After step 2, the above comments should be resized to the width of the viewport.

*Actual*
- The above comments aren't resized to the width of the viewport.
fields.summary: Above source comments aren't resized

fields.description: it should still include the caches of repositories that did shut down
fields.summary: if backup cant stop one repository, no caches are included

fields.description:
this link https://extranet.atlassian.com/crucible/cru/create?csid=<csid>&repo=<repo>

Breaks if there is no mapped committer for the changeset. 

What happens: You click the link, a dialog fails to come up and you are directed to a blank page like this:

!http://img.skitch.com/20091120-7c8uar3yu227m7i5kf54gsihy.jpg!

This is an issue for  plugins using that link to create reviews (such as the JIRA FishEye plugin) using that link to create reviews from changesets. There needs to be some sort of error handling. 

In the normal activity stream, creating a review for an unmapped committer from a changeset sets the logged in user as the author, which doesn't seem to be correct behaviour either. (There should atleast be a warning)
fields.summary: Create review from changeset breaks if there is no mapped committer.

fields.description: When collapsing a folder during a review, there is no way of knowing how many files have been commented on. When collapsed should show the summary of comments on all files within the collapsed package
fields.summary: Show # of comments on collapsed folder

fields.description: After struggling with this after the 2.0 upgrade due to problems with case-sensitivity, but finally seeing it resolved in updates, I was surprised to see that Subversion usernames are now once again showing up in the activity lists.
fields.summary: Usernames show up in list of checkins

fields.description:
The new completeness statistics in Crucible are really useful, but marking them as percentage complete gets confusing when this value is "100% complete". When it says 100%, it appears with a green bar that looks like the reviewer has actually "Completed" the review rather than just having looked at each file.

This is misleading, I think, and it confused me as an author/moderator who didn't actually create the review and I closed the review prematurely.

As for suggestion solutions, I can see a couple:

- you could make it clear that this isn't completeness of the review, but the number of files reviewed - e.g. "100% of files reviewed"
- you could make the percentage artificially lower -- say 95% complete -- until the reviewer actually completes it. Only once the reviewer is really complete would this say 100%.

Of course, there may be another better one.
fields.summary: Review details says "Reviewer is 100% complete" when she hasn't completed the review

fields.description:
File level comments are as wide as the longest source line for a file, instead of as wide as the viewport for the file (inline comments are constrained to this width).

Also, when first loading a review, these is a noticable delay until the inline comments are resized to fit in the viewport.
fields.summary: File comments are too wide

fields.description: After the initial review, I only really care about people's comments. It'd be great to be able to build an RSS feed that only shows me the comments
fields.summary: RSS feeds on comments

fields.description: Just because I click on a file in a review doesn't mean I've finished reviewing it.  The "feature" that turned that on by default really needs to change.  At a minimum, wait until I've scrolled through the whole file.  Really it should be a per-user preference for whether or not that is active.  It's very annoying and ends up hurting the whole team & making reviews less productive, because people will click around and then not realize that they still have things left to review, because the files are marked as read.
fields.summary: Stop marking a file as read when I click on it

fields.description:
*Steps*
1. View the Review History for any review.
2. Click the _Date_ table header to sort by _Date_ ascending.
3. Click it again to sort it descending.

*Expected*
- It sorts the table by date depending on the sort order you requested.

*Actual*
- It's only able to sort by date ascending, even though the arrow points down.
fields.summary: Review History table sort by date is broken in IE

fields.description: No problem, just a feature request
fields.summary: Wiki markup is supported in comments, can doxygen/javadoc be as well?

fields.description:
# friendlier message when suggest reviewers timed out, and add a link/button to re-request with a longer timeout ( https://extranet.atlassian.com/crucible/cru/CR-FE-2752#c23918 )
# set upper bound to the amount of threads that can be spawned from suggest reviewers calculation. set an upper bound to the length of time a thread spawned for suggest reviewers calculation can live (so there won't be any run away threads that take over cpu resources long after the request is completed). (https://extranet.atlassian.com/crucible/cru/CR-FE-2752#c23925 )
# fix the potential problem of a timeout with no error message as described here https://extranet.atlassian.com/crucible/cru/CR-FE-2752#c23928 . 
# add a perf test to detect performance regression https://extranet.atlassian.com/crucible/cru/CR-FE-2752#c23976
fields.summary: make improvements to the implementation of suggest reviewers (rework from review)

fields.description:
When searching for particular files, then selecting the "Add All x Revisions" options, not all files get selected:

!http://img.skitch.com/20091117-t8quia3u6s9y78nn7a6kgx5x27.jpg!

In my test it picked out the oldest and newest versions of now.txt but nothing in between. 

Additionally the screenshot above shows 15 revisions when my test repo only has 10.
fields.summary: "Add All x Revisions" option of search pane of manage files for review doesn't work as expected

fields.description:
When editing the files for a review, under the files tab it allows you to select a particular file for review and a particular revision. By default only the latest is loaded, and there is an option "Load Full History" that will populate the list with the full history of the file.  

!revs.jpg!

Once the all the revisions have been loaded, you need to manually open the list again to pick the particular revision. It would be better if the options refreshed automatically without having to reopen the list.
fields.summary: Automatically expand the list of revisions after selecting "Load Full History" for a file in a review.

fields.description:
Symptoms:

After upgrading from 2.0.x to 2.1 (release), see the following in the logs:

{noformat}
ERROR - Unable to enable plugin com.atlassian.plugins.rest.atlassian-rest-module
...
ERROR - Unable to enable plugin com.atlassian.gadgets.publisher
...
ERROR - Unable to enable plugin com.atlassian.oauth.consumer
...
ERROR - Unable to enable plugin com.atlassian.oauth.admin
...
ERROR - Unable to enable plugin com.atlassian.templaterenderer.atlassian-template-renderer-velocity1.6-plugin
...
ERROR - Unable to enable plugin com.atlassian.oauth.serviceprovider
{noformat}

All failures have the same root cause:

{noformat}
Caused by: org.osgi.framework.BundleException: Unresolved constraint in bundle 32: package; (&(package=org.apache.commons.collections)(version>=3.2.0)(!(version>=4.0.0)))
{noformat}


This is related to commons collections version mismatch
fields.summary: Caused by: org.osgi.framework.BundleException: Unresolved constraint in bundle 32: package; (&(package=org.apache.commons.collections)(version>=3.2.0)(!(version>=4.0.0)))

fields.description:
From a support case:

{quote}
In my report of "10% continuous load", I reported that there was a query being issued twice a second that seemed senseless. It continues:

LOG: duration: 22.992 ms execute S_63: select recipient0_.cru_recipient_id as cru1_40_, recipient0_.cru_email as cru2_40_, recipient0_.cru_rss as cru3_40_, recipient0_.cru_ui_ack as cru4_40_, recipient0_.cru_user_notification_flag as cru5_40_, recipient0_.cru_notification_id as cru6_40_, recipient0_.cru_user as cru7_40_ from cru_recipient recipient0_ where recipient0_.cru_email=$1 or recipient0_.cru_email=$2
DETAIL: parameters: $1 = '1', $2 = '2'
LOG: duration: 25.751 ms execute S_70: select recipient0_.cru_recipient_id as cru1_40_, recipient0_.cru_email as cru2_40_, recipient0_.cru_rss as cru3_40_, recipient0_.cru_ui_ack as cru4_40_, recipient0_.cru_user_notification_flag as cru5_40_, recipient0_.cru_notification_id as cru6_40_, recipient0_.cru_user as cru7_40_ from cru_recipient recipient0_ where recipient0_.cru_email=$1 or recipient0_.cru_email=$2
DETAIL: parameters: $1 = '1', $2 = '2'

This query does not seem connected to any particular action. Reviewing it as per my original report, it seems like:

select * from cru_recipient where cru_email in (1, 2)

In our environment, we have:

crucible=# select cru_email, count(1) from cru_recipient group by cru_email;
cru_email | count
----------+-------
1 | 46
3 | 127346
0 | 9465
(3 rows)

As per the original report, due to the query being prepared - PostgreSQL prepares a conservative plan that makes no assumption about the selectivity of the cru_email field. As a result, the query is particular slowly. It should only scan 46 rows based on selectivity - but without knowledge of selectivity, it does a sequential scan through the 127k rows as well.

Why would it do this query repeatedly?

Note that this is just one specific symptom. Crucible is still slow for us, although it is now "usable".

If I click around through a review against a quad-core Intel Xeon X3330 2.66 Ghz, 4 Gbytes of 800 Mhz RAM, with me being the only user on the system, and I use Firebug - I see that it often makes two or more AJAX calls. In one particular case - clicking on a file in a review, it issues 2 or more AJAX requests, with each taking 200+ milliseconds to complete. Result is that for what should be a simple update - it takes 0.5 seconds to complete. This is a quite noticeable lag.
{quote}
fields.summary: Redundant queries causing load even when system is idle

{code}
     [java] INFO  - FishEye/Crucible 2.1.0.M5 (build-SNAPSHOT), Built on 2009-10-21
     [java] INFO  - Crucible: Commercial License registered to atlassian (eac/cru).
     [java] INFO  - Periodic polling for software updates is enabled (interval is 1 day).
     [java] ERROR - Error while synchronising users:
     [java] com.cenqua.fisheye.rep.DbException: Unexpected error adding user named jxie to the crucible database.
     [java]     at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.UserManager$19.write(UserManager.java:1042)
     [java]     at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.UserManager$19.write(UserManager.java:1001)
     [java]     at com.cenqua.fisheye.config.DB0Handle.write(DB0Handle.java:96)

     [java]     at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.UserManager.resyncAuth(UserManager.java:532)
     [java]     at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.UserManager.resyncAuth(UserManager.java:497)
     [java]     at com.cenqua.fisheye.user.AuthSynchroniser$1.run(AuthSynchroniser.java:44)
     [java]     at java.util.TimerThread.mainLoop(Timer.java:512)
     [java]     at java.util.TimerThread.run(Timer.java:462)
     [java] Caused by: org.hibernate.HibernateException: Hibernate has been shutdown
     [java]     at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.HibernateUtil.currentState(HibernateUtil.java:126)
     [java]     at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.HibernateUtil.currentSession(HibernateUtil.java:117)
     [java]     at com.cenqua.crucible.model.managers.CrucibleUserManager.session(CrucibleUserManager.java:44)
     [java]     at com.cenqua.crucible.model.managers.CrucibleUserManager.getUserByName(CrucibleUserManager.java:68)

h2. Workaround

If you have _Auto-add users to FishEye_ enabled, this issue will not effect users attempting to login to the system.

Otherwise, either:

* wait for synchronisation to re-occur after the specified period (default is 1 hour); or 
* manually force a synchronisation via *Administration > Security > Authentication > Re-Sync*

2) Click on "TestAdminMenu.java" (the last entry in the tree on the left)

fields.description:
Performing a review - such as adding comments or changing the view preferences - is very slow in IE 7.

For example:
1) Load https://atlaseye-qa.atlassian.com/atlaseye/cru/CR-JRA-159
2) Click on "TestAdminMenu.java" (the last entry in the tree on the left)
3) Click Prefs->Side By Side View.
4) Wait 30 seconds for the UI to respond and the page to reload.

Every action - including adding comments, changing preferences, and deleting comments - takes 3-4 times longer in IE than in Firefox. During longer waits, IE does not respond to any input and appears to have hung.

The QA server is slow but not slow enough to justify this - UI responsiveness on Firefox using the same server is reasonable. On IE 7 it is almost unusable.
fields.summary: Performing a review is very slow in IE 7/8

fields.description:
IE7 performs very poorly when view diffs for a review even on a file with ~1500 lines to the point where its near unusable. In particular scrolling is very slow, and loading the files. 

Firefox 3.5 seems to handle the diffs without issue.
fields.summary: Very poor performance viewing diffs in IE7

fields.description:
This has happened to me twice in the last week.

The page that appears just has Crucible header and footer but is otherwise empty.

fields.description:
11:32:50 AM Craig Sharkie: BUG Completed reviewer still has status and hasn't got tick http://img.skitch.com/20091105-cw6creqg6kfpxbkyyqmkg72drb.png
11:33:45 AM Joe Xie: @ sharkie: but is Jeff really completed? or just finished viewing all the files?
11:34:37 AM Craig Sharkie: @joe viewing all files shouldn't show as 100% - there used to be math to stop that
11:35:09 AM Anna Buttfield: @craig - no, there never was in that case, and i don't think thats a problem
11:36:21 AM Anna Buttfield: i think its valid for the reviewer to have viewed all files and comments and have their status at 100% done but not completed
11:36:37 AM tim: +1
11:38:04 AM Craig Sharkie: @anna I agree, but the issue then is in them be "completed" :) Maybe if the Overview said "100% progress"
fields.summary: reviewer completion % confusing
